title-group.article-title: A Cost-Effectiveness Evaluation of Hospital Discharge Counseling by Pharmacists

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pharmacy Practice and Science, College of Pharmacy, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, USA

author-notes.corresp: Edward P. Armstrong, Department of Pharmacy Practice and Science, 1295 N Martin Ave, College of Pharmacy, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA Email: armstrong@pharmacy.arizona.edu

abstract.p: Objectives: This study estimated the cost-effectiveness of pharmacist discharge counseling on medication-related morbidity in both the high-risk elderly and general US population. Methods: A cost-effectiveness decision analytic model was developed using a health care system perspective based on published clinical trials. Costs included direct medical costs, and the effectiveness unit was patients discharged without suffering a subsequent adverse drug event. A systematic review of published studies was conducted to estimate variable probabilities in the cost-effectiveness model. To test the robustness of the results, a second-order probabilistic sensitivity analysis (Monte Carlo simulation) was used to run 10 000 cases through the model sampling across all distributions simultaneously. Results: Pharmacist counseling at hospital discharge provided a small, but statistically significant, clinical improvement at a similar overall cost. Pharmacist counseling was cost saving in approximately 48% of scenarios and in the remaining scenarios had a low willingness-to-pay threshold for all scenarios being cost-effective. In addition, discharge counseling was more cost-effective in the high-risk elderly population compared to the general population. Conclusion: This cost-effectiveness analysis suggests that discharge counseling by pharmacists is quite cost-effective and estimated to be cost saving in over 48% of cases. High-risk elderly patients appear to especially benefit from these pharmacist services.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Medication errors and their consequences are serious issues that need to be addressed by health care systems. Medication errors can happen at any stage within the medication-use process, including prescribing, dispensing, administering, and monitoring. 1 Medication errors occur frequently and their incidence has been estimated to range from 12.3 to 1400 per 1000 patients. 2–6 Hospital discharge is a critical point during which patients are more likely to experience medication errors, some of which can lead to adverse drug events (ADEs). 7–9 The elderly (typically defined as those individuals 65 years of age or older) are at an especially high risk of experiencing medication errors. 10,11 Adverse drug events contribute to many negative consequences including additional physician visits, secondary treatments, emergency department (ED) visits, hospital admissions, long-term care admissions, and possibly death. 12,13 These consequences cause the annual cost of drug-related morbidity and mortality to be estimated at $177.4 billion (year 2000 US$). 12

According to the Institute of Medicine, several strategies, including patient counseling, can be used to prevent medication errors. 1 Specifically, research by Kuyper indicates that 89% of medication errors can be detected by patient counseling. 1,14 Patient counseling, which is considered to be an important component of pharmaceutical care and medication reconciliation, 7,15–21 provides the opportunity for pharmacists and patients to communicate more effectively using direct, open-ended questions. 22 This allows pharmacists to investigate the patients' needs so that pharmacists can “fill in the gaps of knowledge.” Most routine patient counseling by pharmacists is typically not time intensive 15,16,22 and is considered an intervention to improve medication adherence. 23,24 Medication adherence has been shown to lead to medical savings as a result of fewer ED visits and hospitalizations, with benefit–cost ratio 24 ranging from 2:1 to 13:1. However, although most patients receive some type of written information with their prescriptions, only 43% to 64% of patients are routinely provided medication counseling by pharmacists. 25,26 Although the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (OBRA)90) required pharmacists to offer medication counseling to Medicaid patients, this policy change was adopted by all 50 states to require pharmacists to provide medication counseling to all patients, not just Medicaid patients. However, oral counseling of patients by pharmacists has not been routinely enforced or implemented. 25,27

Hospital discharge is a critical transition for patients because after that point their health care is less structured and they are often responsible for their own medication administration and monitoring. Therefore, it is important that patients understand their prescribed medication before leaving the hospital. In addition, hospital discharge provides pharmacists an opportunity to detect medication errors during the counseling process. 7,14,16,17,19,21 However, time constraints, staffing demands, and reimbursement for counseling services have often been barriers cited when facilities decide not to offer pharmacist discharge counseling programs. 26,28 No studies were identified in the published literature that had evaluated the cost-effectiveness of discharge counseling by pharmacists.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of pharmacist discharge counseling on medication-related morbidity in both the high-risk elderly and general US population. The study objectives were to estimate the direct medical costs and clinical impact of pharmacist discharge counseling on medication errors and the subsequent impact of ADEs, ED visits, and hospital readmissions from a health care system’s perspective.

sec.title: Model Design
sec.p: A cost-effectiveness decision analytic model was developed using a health care system perspective based on published clinical trials. Cost included direct medical costs and the effectiveness unit was defined as patients discharged from the hospital without suffering a subsequent ADE. A systematic review of published studies was conducted to estimate variable probabilities in the cost-effectiveness model. The literature review included well-conducted case–control or cohort studies.

sec.title: Data Collection and Selection
sec.p: Literature searches were conducted using the PubMed and Google Scholar databases for the years 1990 to 2010. Studies were identified using the following keywords: discharge counseling, medication reconciliation, medication error, adverse drug events, emergency department, hospitalization, and readmission. In identified articles, if the reference citations were related to discharge counseling and its impact, they were also evaluated for inclusion in the data extraction process.

sec.title: Data Extraction and Analysis
sec.p: The selected full articles were reviewed. Articles were included if they described (1) interventions or activities that included pharmacist-provided counseling; (2) outcomes related to medication counseling, such as rate reduction of medication errors; (3) high-risk patients, patients receiving polypharmacy; or (4) patients with chronic diseases.

The exclusion criteria for articles were the following: (1) counseling services not related to medication (eg, smoking cessation counseling, nutrition counseling, and drug-dependency counseling); (2) counseling not conducted by pharmacists; and (3) counseling that did not include interactive communication between patients and pharmacists.
Model variables related to hospital discharge counseling and the impact of medication-related morbidity are provided in Table 1. Resource use variables are shown in Table 2.

tr.td: Model variables for pharmacist discharge counseling
Percentage of medication errors detected during discharge counseling by pharmacists
Odds ratio of emergency department visits in counseling group compared with controls
Odds ratio of readmission in counseling group compared with controls
Model variables for the impact of medication-related morbidity
Percentage of high-risk elderly patients having adverse drug events from medication errors
Percentage of discharged high-risk elderly who did not receive discharge counseling by a pharmacist to have a subsequent emergency department
Percentage of discharged high-risk elderly who did not receive discharge counseling by a pharmacist to have a subsequent hospital readmission
Probability of having an adverse drug event as a result of a medication error in the general population
Probability of having an adverse drug event without a medication error in the general population
Percentage of high-risk elderly who did not receive discharge counseling by a pharmacist that had a subsequent emergency department visit
Percentage of the general population who had an adverse drug event resulting in a subsequent emergency department visit
Percentage of the general population who had an adverse drug event resulting in a subsequent hospital readmission
Percentage of discharged patients who were elderly
Percentage of elderly patients who did not receive discharge counseling by a pharmacist who experienced a medication error
Percentage of the general population who did not receive discharge counseling by a pharmacist to have a subsequent medication error
Time pharmacists spent counseling each patient (minutes)
Cost of an emergency department visit (US$)

sec.title: Patient Counseling by Pharmacists
sec.p: The cost-effectiveness model was designed to estimate the impact of patient counseling by pharmacists. Therefore, the model was a representation of possible consequences of patient counseling and subsequent medication errors. Discharge counseling by pharmacists to “fill gaps” in patient knowledge was considered to be the pharmacists' intervention. 22 Based on the published literature identified, a review of a patient’s history, telephone counseling, education, and patient discharge interviews were all classified as meeting the definition of pharmacist counseling of patients in the cost-effectiveness model. 19–21 In the model, high-risk elderly were defined as patients 65 years of age or older while the “general population” was defined to be patients of all ages, except those 65 years or older.

Using variables identified in the published literature, the model estimated the proportion of patients that had a medication error based on patient characteristics (high-risk elderly or general population) and whether they had counseling by a pharmacist. The model then estimated the proportion of patients that had an ADE. An ADE was defined as a preventable injury resulting from medication use. 9 Once a patient experienced an ADE, the model incorporated the proportion of patients that required additional medical treatment such as an ED visit or hospital admission. The effectiveness outcome in the model was defined as patients not having an ADE.

sec.title: Medication errors
sec.p: Kuyper reported that patient counseling was able to detect 89% of all medication errors. 14 The model incorporated these data and assumed that all medication errors detected were accurate. Therefore, it was estimated that the probability of medication errors was decreased to 11% of the total mediation errors when counseling by pharmacists was provided. Therefore, 0.11 was the variable used for the percentage decrease in medication errors as a result of medication error detection by pharmacists during counseling.

sec.title: Emergency department visit
sec.p: Walker et al reported that 22 (6%) of 358 patients who received discharge counseling by pharmacists had ED readmissions within 14 days after discharge compared to 27 (7.4%) of 366 of the patients who did not receive discharge counseling. 21 The odds ratio produced by this study was 0.82, indicating that patients who received discharge counseling had 0.82 times the risk of ED readmissions compared to the patients who did not receive discharge counseling. This odds ratio was converted to a probability and used as the variable to account for the impact of counseling on ED readmissions.

Forster et al reported 11% of patients who had ADEs went to an ED within 2 to 5 weeks after discharge. 9 Therefore, the probability of visiting the ED due to an ADE in the discharged general population was assumed to be 0.11 (Table 2).

sec.title: Readmission
sec.p: Forster et al reported 24% of patients who had ADEs had ED readmissions 2 to 5 weeks after discharge. 9 Therefore, the probability of having a hospital readmission was assumed to be 0.24 in the discharged general population. Walker et al reported an adjusted odds ratio of 0.46 of being readmitted to the hospital within 14 days for patients who received discharge counseling by pharmacists compared to patients who did not receive discharge counseling after adjusting for patient age, sex, and race in their regression analysis. 21 This odd ratio was converted to a probability and used as the variable to estimate hospital readmissions for the high-risk elderly who had received hospital discharge counseling by a pharmacist.

sec.title: Cost of Providing Discharge Counseling
sec.p: Based on the published literature, it was estimated that 16 minutes of pharmacist time would be needed to provide discharge counseling to each patient. 20,29–31 To account for this activity, the pharmacist cost was included for counseling and it was assumed that additional pharmacy technician time would be needed to account for the loss of pharmacist productivity in dispensing when pharmacist counseling was implemented. The published literature 29 indicated that pharmacy technicians spend 2.11 (±0.363) minutes processing a prescription, while pharmacists spend 1.86 (±0.552) minutes. These times were incorporated into the model using pharmacy technicians' average wage of $5.26 and the pharmacists' average wage of $51.27 (Table 2 ). Therefore, the total cost of providing discharge counseling per patient was the combination of the cost due to technician prescription processing time and pharmacist providing discharge counseling.

sec.title: Cost of ADEs
sec.p: The model relied on the Ernst and Grizzle study for cost estimates. 12 Specifically, the following costs were used: the cost of an ED was $464.54; and the cost of readmission per patient was $19 073.32. 12,32 Both of these costs were adjusted from May 2000 to October 2010 prices using the customer prize index (CPI) annual inflation rate. 12,32 Outpatient physicians visit costs and additional medication costs were not included in the analysis of ADEs, as it was assumed that these resource units and costs would be equal in both the discharge counseling group and the control group.

sec.title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis
sec.p: A health system perspective was used for this cost-effectiveness analysis. The decision analytic model was developed using TreeAge Pro 2009 Software Inc (Williamstown, Massachusetts). The structure of the model is summarized in Figure 1 . The clinical outcome of treatment success was defined as the absence of an ADE within 1 month after hospital discharge. Clinical failure was defined in the model as patients having an ADE within 1 month after hospital discharge.

caption.p: Decision analytic model comparing pharmacist discharge counseling to no discharge counseling.

sec.p: Beta distributions were used for chance node probabilities in the model because it restricts values between 0 and 1. Gamma distributions were used for cost variables because it used nonnegative values and these data were right skewed. The cost-effectiveness output was cost per successfully treated patient (ie, cost per patient not having an ADE). To test the robustness of the results, a second-order probabilistic sensitivity analysis (Monte Carlo simulation) was used to run 10 000 cases through the model sampling across all distributions simultaneously. The analysis included a cost-effectiveness scatter plot from the probabilistic sensitivity analysis, comparing the 95% confidence interval (CI) between treatment groups for both costs and success. Incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs) were calculated to determine the impact of discharge counseling. The cost-effectiveness scatter plot was used to identify the baseline and comparator products for the ICER analyses. In addition, a cost-effectiveness acceptability curves (CEACs) were also calculated to determine the impact of different willingness-to-pay values.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The results from the Monte Carlo simulation estimated that there was a small, but statistically significant difference in the proportion of patients not having ADEs (ie, successfully treated patients) when counseled by a pharmacist at hospital discharge. Although quite similar, the cost-effectiveness scatter plot demonstrates that 95% CIs did not overlap between the effectiveness rates (Figure 2 ). However, this clinical improvement occurred without an overall increase in health system costs. The mean cost was $25 (95% CI 19-33) with pharmacist discharge counseling and $25 (95% CI 19-32) without pharmacist counseling. Since there was overlap in the 95% CIs, there was no statistically significant difference in cost between providing or not providing pharmacist discharge counseling Table 3. Overall, these data indicate that there was a significant increase in the number of patients successfully treated with pharmacist discharge counseling at no increased cost compared to patients that did not receive counseling.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics From the Monte Carlo Simulation

sec.p: The ICER scatter plot is seen in Figure 3 . This figure clearly shows the location of the incremental effectiveness data to the right of the vertical axis, indicating that discharge counseling led to a significantly larger number of patients successfully treated (ie, did not have an ADE). Figure 3 also reveals that 48.3% of the points were in the lower right quadrant where discharge counseling was both more effective and less costly than no counseling (ie, pharmacist discharge counseling dominated no counseling by being both more effective and less costly). Figure 3 also reveals that 51.7% of the data points fall in the upper right quadrant where discharge counseling was both more effective and more costly.

The CEAC further clarified the ICER results by examining different willingness-to-pay thresholds and the probability of pharmacist counseling being cost-effective (Figure 4 ). This graph demonstrates that at a low willingness-to-pay value (approximately $10 000 per successfully treated patient) pharmacist discharge counseling resulted in a high probability of being cost-effective across in all scenarios. Thus, although pharmacist discharge counseling was cost saving in approximately 48% of scenarios, it was still a very cost-effective service as all scenarios were cost-effective at a low willingness-to-pay value.

When the data were restricted to the high-risk elderly, pharmacist counseling was even more cost-effective. When discharge counseling a high-risk elderly patient, the average effectiveness was 1.0 (95% CI 0.99-1.0) and the average cost was $21 (95% CI 16-27) compared to no counseling where the average effectiveness was 0.98 (95% CI 0.97-0.98) and the average cost was $48 (95% CI 38-60). Of note, in 100% of scenarios, discharge counseling of high-risk elderly patients dominated no counseling by being both more effective and less costly compared to not counseling. Thus, these data demonstrate that discharge counseling by pharmacists was more cost-effective in the high-risk elderly population compared to the general population.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study provides additional information regarding the benefits and costs of when pharmacists provide discharge counseling to patients at hospital discharge. Overall, this service reduced ADEs and was cost saving in 48% of scenarios. With the low willingness-to-pay value noted in Figure 4, discharge counseling was shown to be quite cost-effective across all scenarios.

When the cost-effectiveness analysis was restricted to the subpopulation of high-risk elderly patients, this analysis found that discharge counseling by pharmacists was even more cost-effective compared to the general population. In addition, since elderly patients often take several medications, they are more likely to experience medication errors. 3,16,18 Moreover, since many body functions decline with age, if elderly patients do experience an ADE, the adverse effect may cause more harm. 33 These data support the benefit of hospitals providing discharge counseling by pharmacists and strongly indicate that priority should be given to high-risk elderly patients.

Although no previous cost-effectiveness analysis of discharge counseling by pharmacists has been published, it is an important professional service and has been supported by discussions regarding the provision of pharmaceutical care, medication therapy management (MTM), and telephone consultation. For example, in examining other pharmacy services, Isetts et al reported that total health expenditure in patients with hypertension and dyslipidemia were reduced from $11 965 to $8197 per person (n = 186, P < .0001) by providing pharmacist-managed MTM. 34 Other researchers have shown that pharmacist-coordinated telephone counseling was cost-effective compared to a control group (£187.7 vs £282.2, P < .0001). 35

The finding in the current analysis that high-risk elderly patients especially benefit from pharmacist discharge counseling corresponds with that of Etermad and Hay who noted that high-risk elderly patients benefited from the provision of pharmaceutical care ($2100 per life year saved). 36

There were several key limitations to this analysis. For example, there were a limited number of published trials identified that could be used to construct the decision tree model. The Institute of Medicine acknowledges there is a lack of research regarding the incidence, costs, and consequences of medication errors. 22 In addition, although some studies were identified that addressed an aspect of patient counseling, they had to be excluded from the model because their results could not be transformed into monetary units. Therefore, this analysis relied heavily on the studies by Kuyper and Walker et al. Results from these 2 clinical trials served as the basis to estimate the impact of discharge counseling on medication errors, ED visits, and hospital readmissions. 14,21 Furthermore, due to the dearth of studies that reported outcome in both life years saved and utility units, it was not possible to include cost per life year saved or cost per quality-adjusted life years gained in this study.

Further research is needed to more carefully examine the range of other patient subgroups that are likely to benefit from pharmacist discharge counseling. In addition, research is needed to examine pharmacist roles in a broad range of treatment settings. Currently, very limited research has been conducted to examine the effectiveness and utility of pharmacist counseling. Studies involving counseling service in ambulatory settings should be done as well as further work regarding hospital discharge counseling. 25,26

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This analysis suggests that pharmacist discharge counseling is quite cost-effective and is estimated to be cost saving in over 48% of cases. High-risk elderly patients appear to benefit more than the general population. Further clinical trials are needed to examine additional patient subgroups as well as practice settings to determine the cost-effectiveness of pharmacist services in diverse environments.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no extramural financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
